client: Bob McLean, Municipality of West Perth
gravity_system: Basement Beam, Beam Pocket, Strip Footing, Concrete Floor Slab
key_elements: Telepost, Beam Pocket, Radon Mitigation, Drainage Layer
overall_building_description: The structural design for the basement at 26 Nelson St. involves a detailed load path analysis focusing on the replacement of temporary wood posts with teleposts rated for a minimum factored load of 6,000 lbs. These teleposts are to be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations and securely fastened to the bottom flange of the basement beam, ensuring effective load transfer and structural stability. The basement beam plan highlights the necessity for beam pockets and radon mitigation measures, with a 4-inch concrete floor slab providing the primary load-bearing surface. The proposed footing detail specifies a widened strip footing measuring 36 inches by 18 inches by 10 inches, which is to be doweled into the existing strip footing using three 15M epoxied dowels with a 4-inch embedment, ensuring a robust connection and continuity of load transfer. The footing is supported by a 6-inch compacted granular fill, providing adequate bearing capacity and minimizing settlement risks. The design incorporates a drainage layer and continuous insulation to address moisture control and thermal performance, with 1/2-inch anchor bolts spaced at 16 inches on center providing lateral stability. The use of 2x4 spruce studs at 24 inches on center, combined with R12 Roxul insulation and a vapour barrier, enhances the thermal envelope and complies with energy efficiency standards. The structural adequacy of the design is confirmed by Waddell Engineering Ltd., aligning with the Ontario Building Code requirements. The construction details emphasize the importance of precise joint configurations, reinforcement layouts, and embedment details, with a focus on ensuring the integrity of the load path from the beam to the foundation. The spatial relationships between the grid connections and section relationships are meticulously detailed, ensuring seamless integration and alignment of structural components. The proposed repair strategy highlights the critical role of teleposts in maintaining structural integrity, with specific attention to the installation sequence and fastening methods to optimize load distribution and minimize deflection. The design also considers site-specific conditions, such as radon mitigation and moisture control, to ensure long-term durability and performance. The use of engineering jargon and technical terminology throughout the design documentation underscores the precision and rigor of the structural analysis, with a focus on achieving optimal load transfer, lateral stability, and compliance with relevant codes and standards. The fabrication requirements and assembly sequences are clearly delineated, ensuring efficient construction and adherence to best practices in structural engineering. The design's emphasis on technical specifications, such as material grades, bolt sizes, and weld types, reflects a commitment to quality and performance, with a comprehensive approach to addressing potential challenges and ensuring the successful execution of the structural design.
